Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Situation2: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Story: Tonight is the only evening I have free with Mia before I leave for a week-long conference. She’s been looking forward to this—she even made my favorite pasta. As I sit across from her, I can see the anticipation in her eyes, the way she leans in, hoping for undivided attention. But my phone buzzes with a pharmacy newsletter notification. I remember the new drug releases I promised myself I’d review before the trip. My mind splits: Mia deserves my focus, but my profession demands I stay sharp and informed. I try to listen to her story about her day, but my thoughts drift to the clinical updates I might miss. I feel the weight of her expectation for closeness and my own responsibility to my patients. My heart aches with guilt as I wrestle with the urge to sneak a glance at the newsletter, knowing that either choice means letting someone down.
